title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: I don't remember of any prayer meetings or minister's classes except preparatory to the Communionup to this time ; but I have since understood that MrBruce had a class for young men in his house atLauriston Place, which was well attended, and wasexceedingly useful to many. Our parish was thesouth side of the Lawnmarket and Castlehill, whereMr Bruce had a meeting under the charge of amissionary, Mr Waddel, afterwards minister at Stow,and where Mr Bruce sometimes officiated on Sabbathevenings.

title: Friends, Lovers, Chocolate
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: Isabel sat back in her seat. Before the taxi turned, to make its way along Lauriston Place, she looked back to the end of Forrest Road, half expecting to see Graeme appear, coming round the corner. But she did not see him and she upbraided herself for her overactive imagination.

title: The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie
author: Spark, Muriel
snippet: They had come to the end of Lauriston Place, past the fire station, where they were to get on a tram car to go to tea with Miss Brodie in her flat at Churchhill. A very long queue of men lined this part of the street.

title: John and Betty's Scotch history visit,
author: Williamson, Margaret. [from old catalog]
snippet: ^* Heriot's foundation is very famous, John, though, of course, it's not as old as the Eoyal High School, founded eight hundred years ago by the Holyrood monks." They were going along Lauriston Place on their walk towards Greyfriars Church, as Mrs. Pitt spoke. ^* The monks meant only to educate those boys who sang for them at mass, but the school became very popular, and others wished to attend.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Heriofs Hospital, (Lauriston Place, by George IV. Bridge and Forest Road.) Admittance every day except Saturday, by order obtained at the Treasurer's Office, No. 11 Royal Exchange. This building, one of the proudest ornaments of the city, owes its foundation to George Heriot, jeweller to James VI., whose name will probably be more familiar to the ear of strangers as the "jingling Geordie" of" The Fortunes of Nigel."
